review.title: NPCs Vote! Changing Voter Reactions Over Time Using the Extreme AI Personality Engine
review.abstract: Can non-player characters have human-realistic personalities, changing over time depending on input from those around them? And can they have different reactions and thoughts about different people? Using Extreme AI, a psychology-based personality engine using the Five Factor model of personality, I answer these questions by creating personalities for 100 voters and allowing them to react to two politicians to see if the NPC voters' choice of candidate develops in a realistic-seeming way, based on initial and changing personality facets and on their differing feelings toward the politicians (in this case, across liking, trusting, and feeling affiliated with the candidates). After 16 test runs, the voters did indeed change their attitudes and feelings toward the candidates in different and yet generally realistic ways, and even changed their attitudes about other issues based on what a candidate extolled.

sections.text: Index terms - artificial intelligence, personality, non-player characters, video gamesI. INTRODUCTION AND OBJECTIVE on-player characters are everywhere in most game worlds; they are the shopkeepers, the bureaucrats, the guards, the bartenders... in fact almost all the inhabitants of each city or city. But they are as faceless as they are numerous, and they act in predetermined (and usually simplistic) ways that do not allow them to act autonomously, much less to react to events or change their minds in a realistic way over time. This project focuses on creating NPCs with human-like personalities that use the Extreme AI (ExAI) personality machine, and then tests whether these NPCs can react and change due to external stimuli - in this case (and in this interesting US election year) on politicians who are each trying to win the votes of 100 NPCs.

sections.heading: II. WHAT IS EXTREME AI?
sections.text: It uses the five-factor model of personality [1] to create 30 facet scores based on the personality of each character (see Table 1), ranging from 0-100 as rated for a real person on the NEO-PI (a test that evaluates facets in the model; see [2]). In addition, ExAI allows these facets to change over time, based on various models of personality change and elasticity [3], although it is generally much faster than in real life, so a player can see these changes over time.

sections.heading: IV. USING EXTREME AI TO CREATE NPC VOTERS AND SETTING UP THE VOTING SIM

sections.heading: A. The Voters
sections.text: For this simulation, we create 100 voters of different political and personal sensitivities, and, given different candidate scenarios, they survey who would vote for them (if they would vote at all). Ideally, voters would pursue their political and personal inclinations, especially once the candidates become apparent; for example, a staunch conservative would be extremely likely to vote conservative.

sections.heading: B. The Politicians
sections.text: This is a campaign based on personalities and on one of the hottest topics (rabbits running the country): Voters choose a candidate and decide how well a politician is perceived - how popular, trustworthy, efficient and reliable he is. Politicians start with a certain amount of baggage, taking years of politics and public opinion forming for example: • Brian Jackson (Conservative): Very charismatic, a bit of a fool and often says unpleasant things; also you don't always get something done. • Len Kingston (Liberal): Not particularly likeable and seen as a bit of a backroom trader, but he is extremely efficient and speaks much better than Jackson.The candidate's baggage can be undone way or they can get the same baggage in the simulation. For this simulation, we start with the same baggage of each candidate, then we change it to see if the voters "opinions are trustworthy.

sections.heading: A. Test runs
sections.text: In the first five runs, we chose, from Jackson's point of view, choice three (too promising) in the first round and choice two (with his own report) in the second. Afterwards, we chose Jackson, who joked about rabbits, then claimed he would get rid of them, and then he talked about building a fence. For the sake of consistency, these decisions were made regardless of voters "feelings about rabbits. The next five runs were from Kingston's point of view. We chose the second choice in the first round (not too promising), then choice two (with his own report). Kingston is very positive for the rabbits, first you love them, then you kiss them (to show that they are lovable), and then you rant and talk about building a fence. Again, the rabbit decisions were made regardless of public preference or the fact that the answers to this question were not credible to Jackson.
